```{r}
#a. Write the codes
respondents <- c(1:20)
sex <- c(2, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 2)
fathers_occ <- c(1, 3, 3, 3, 1, 2, 3, 1, 1, 1, 3, 2, 1, 3, 3, 1, 3, 1, 2, 1)

house_type <- c(1, 2, 3, 1, 1, 3, 3, 1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 2)

info <- data.frame("Respondednts" = respondents, "Sex" = sex, "Fathers Occupation" = fathers_occ, "Persons at home" = persons_home, "Siblings at school" = siblings_at_school, "Types of houses" = house_type)

#b. Describe the data. Get the structure or the summary of the data
# The data contains information about students' personal information
str(info)

#c. Is the mean number of siblings attending 5?
mean(siblings_at_school)
#The answer is 2.95 so no.

#d. Extract the 1st two rows and then all the columns using the sub-setting functions.
#Write the codes and its output.
info_subset <- info[1:2,]

#e. Extract 3rd and 5th row with 2nd and 4th column. Write the codes and its result.

print(info_subset2)

#f. Select the variable types of houses then store the vector that results as types_houses.
#Write the codes.

types_houses <- info$Types.of.houses

#g. Select only all Males respondent that their father occupation was farmer. Write the
#codes and its output.
M_Farmer <- info[info$Sex == 1 & info$Fathers.Occupation == 1, ]
M_Farmer

#h. Select only all females respondent that have greater than or equal to 5 number of
#siblings attending school. Write the codes and its outputs.
F_Siblings <- info[info$Sex == 2 & info$Siblings.at.school >= 5, ]
F_Siblings
```

###3
```{r}
#Create a .csv file of this. Save it as HouseholdData.csv

#a. Import the csv file into the R environment. Write the codes.
HouseholdData <- read.csv("HouseholdData.csv")
print(HouseholdData)

#b. Convert the Sex into factor using factor() function and change it into integer.[Legend:
#Male = 1 and Female = 2]. Write the R codes and its output.

sex_factor <- factor(HouseholdData$Sex, levels = c("Male", "Female"))
sex_integer <- as.integer(sex_factor)
table(HouseholdData$Sex, sex_integer)
str(HouseholdData)

print(sex_factor)
print(sex_integer)

#c. Convert the Type of Houses into factor and change it into integer. [Legend: Wood
#= 1; Congrete = 2; Semi-Congrete = 3]. Write the R codes and its output.
house_type_factor <- factor(HouseholdData$Types.of.Houses, levels = c("Wood", "Congrete", "Semi-Congrete"))
house_type_integer <- as.integer(house_type_factor)

house_type_factor
house_type_integer

#d. On fatherâ€™s occupation, factor it as Farmer = 1; Driver = 2; and Others = 3. What
#is the R code and its output?
occupation_labels <- c("Farmer", "Driver", "Others")
occupation_text <- occupation_labels[HouseholdData$Fathers.Occupation]
fathers_occ_factor <- factor(occupation_text, levels = c("Farmer", "Driver", "Others"))
fathers_occ_integer <- as.integer(fathers_occ_factor)

fathers_occ_factor
fathers_occ_integer

#e. Select only all females respondent that has a father whose occupation is driver. Write
#the codes and its output.

HouseholdData[HouseholdData$Sex == 2 && HouseholdData$Fathers.Occupation == 2,]
```
